node.title: China, Russia Ask U.N. to End Sanctions so North Korea Can Import Bolts, Utensils, Vacuums
node.description: China and Russia's resolution aims to lift sanctions "with the intent of enhancing the livelihood of the civilian population" of North Korea.

node.title: Progressives Blame Dropped Liberal Policies in Biden Bills for Democrats' Virginia Defeat
node.description: "We can't control the external circumstances, but we can control getting things done," Democratic Representative Ro Khanna of California said.

node.title: Trump Official Ben Carson Calls COVID Vaccine 'Giant Experiment,' Questions Shot for Kids
node.description: Carson, a former pediatric neurosurgeon, questioned the long-term risks of the COVID-19 vaccine and said it makes "no sense" to vaccinate children.

node.title: Gun Rights Lawyer Tells SCOTUS Concealed Carry Bans in NY Stadiums, Subway May Be OK
node.description: SCOTUS began hearing arguments Wednesday for its biggest case on guns in over a decade.

node.title: COP26 a 'blokes’ space' says former female conference president
node.description: Despite being among the most vulnerable from climate change, women and girls are not adequately represented in COP26 climate negotiations, says former climate summit president.

node.title: Fair Work rules every farm worker on every farm entitled a minimum rate of pay
node.description: In what the union describes as one of the most significant industrial decisions of modern times, the Fair Work Commission rules workers picking fruit on a piece rate must be guaranteed a minimum wage.

node.title: The Olympic hopefuls who are relying on raw talent — not coaches — in their bid for gold
node.description: Australia's breakdancing community is getting ready to compete for selection with the sport set to make its debut in Olympic competition at the Paris Games in 2024, though there are no rules or set plan on how to earn a place on the podium.

node.title: Man charged after allegedly fleeing Hobart hotel quarantine during bus transfer
node.description: Police arrest a man who escaped while being transferred between quarantine hotels in Hobart yesterday evening.

node.title: Booker Prize won by South African writer Damon Galgut for multi-generational saga
node.description: Judges described the novel, which spans from 1986 to contemporary, post-apartheid South Africa, as a "master of the form" that "pushes the form in new ways".

node.title: TV going fuzzy? Your neighbour's solar panels might be to blame
node.description: Few things are more frustrating than the television picture breaking up in the middle of your favourite show. Plenty of everyday objects could be interfering with your signal.

node.title: Bushfire bunkers save lives — so why is red tape making it so hard to install them?
node.description: As another hot summer looms, a former intelligence chief warns bushfires will claim more lives if politicians fail to introduce Australia-wide bunker installation standards.

node.title: Hundreds of Covid-19 cases waiting to hear on isolation
node.description: Just 294 people with Covid-19 in the current outbreak are in MIQ facilities, says the Ministry of Business Innovation and Employment.

node.title: COP26: World leaders meeting ends, negotiators take over
node.description: Today was the second and final day of the leaders meeting at the UN COP26 climate change summit in Glasgow.

node.title: Counterfeit products flood internet ahead of holidays
node.description: One business owner said hundreds of third-party sellers are selling counterfeit versions of his product online.

node.title: Senate Democrats again fail to overcome GOP opposition to voting rights bill
node.description: The Senate voted against debating voting legislation Wednesday, with Republicans this time filibustering an update to the landmark Voting Rights Act.

node.title: U.S. Air Force hits its vaccine deadline with nearly all troops vaccinated.
node.description: While the Air Force has the earliest deadline, active duty members in all branches are nearing their goals — until Reserve and National Guard forces are counted.

node.title: Ukraine Pivots, Sounds Alarm About Around 90K Russian Troops Not Far From Border
node.description: Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said that "Russia maintains troops presence on its territory wherever it deems necessary."

node.title: Russia Says 'Hope is the Last to Die' As Date Set for Next Iran Nuclear Talks
node.description: "I believe it is too early to be pessimistic," Mikhail Ulyanov, Russia's represenative in Vienna, told Newsweek as the seventh round of nuclear deal talks was set for November 29.

node.title: Hope in 'Short Supply': Death Toll Hits 23 in Nigerian Building Collapse, Dozens Missing
node.description: Rescue workers were able to rescue nine people by Tuesday, but no survivors were uncovered Wednesday.

node.title: Turkey the Squirrel Delights Internet by Holding Woman's Hand in Viral Video
node.description: The video was posted by Cindy Jenkins, Turkey's former caretaker.

node.title: Climate Summit Turns Its Focus to a Contentious Question: Who Pays?
node.description: Even as financial institutions vowed to mobilize trillions in capital toward clean energy, developing countries say they are still struggling to pay the costs of adapting to the dangers of global warming.

node.title: How We Hug Now
node.description: We’re still figuring it out.

node.title: Video Footage Showed at Least 1 Child Near Site Minutes Before Drone Strike in Kabul
node.description: An investigation of the airstrike, which mistakenly killed 10 civilians, including seven children, did not recommend any disciplinary action.

node.title: Children 5 to 11 in N.Y.C. can start getting Covid shots Thursday, the mayor said.
node.description: The city was awaiting the arrival of federal clinical guidelines for providers before administering shots, the mayor said, though the state said the city did not have to wait.

node.title: The New Magazine Alexander Hamilton Might Have Written For
node.description: National Development calls for a strong government guiding a more self-sufficient economy.

node.title: Fed Alters Projection on Inflation, Says It Could Stick Around Longer Than Expected
node.description: The Federal Reserve will cut billions of dollars in aid in response to new timelines that show inflation may endure into the middle of next year.

node.title: COVID-19 Patients Facing Choice Between Amputated Limbs or Death
node.description: One mother had to let her 10-year-old son go after doctors gave him a 25 percent chance of survival if his arms and legs were amputated.

node.title: 'We have not taken lightly the decision for some areas to require vaccination'
node.description: PM Jacinda Ardern says it was always her view that the government would not force all New Zealanders to be vaccinated and that view had not changed.

node.title: Damon Galgut Wins Booker Prize for ‘The Promise’
node.description: The novelist, shortlisted for two of his previous books, received one of the world’s most prestigious literary awards for his cutting depiction of a white family in post-apartheid South Africa.

node.title: Lawmakers Ask Biden to Rescind Medals for Wounded Knee Massacre
node.description: Seventeen members of Congress said they believed it was within President Biden’s authority to revoke Medals of Honor “when appropriate.”

node.title: India Walton concedes to the write-in incumbent, Byron Brown, in the race for Buffalo’s mayor.
node.description: “It seems unlikely that we will end up with enough votes to inaugurate a Walton administration in January,” the democratic socialist wrote on Twitter.

node.title: Who Can Make mRNA Vaccines?
node.description: Many health advocates say a key solution is to make the shots in the regions that still don’t have them. I wanted to know whether there were companies that could do it.

node.title: Newsmax, OAN Accused of Running 2020 Election 'Disinformation Campaign'
node.description: Smartmatic's defamation claims about Newsmax and OAN follow similar allegations the company made about Fox News earlier this year.

node.title: Is 'Ballot Harvesting' a Threat to Local Elections? Ron DeSantis Wants to Make It a Felony
node.description: The Republican governor announced several proposed changes that he said "will make Florida the number one state for elections."

node.title: What will fully vaccinated travellers need to do to enter Queensland?
node.description: In 15 days, Queensland will move one step closer to reopening its borders to interstate hotspots, but just how easy will it be to actually enter the state and what requirements will travellers need?

node.title: Forgotten World Highway's future sealed
node.description: One of the last stretches of unsealed state highway in the country is now a step closer to being smothered in tarmac.

node.title: All Blacks coach confident rugby can tackle concussion problem
node.description: The All Blacks are confident New Zealand and World Rugby are doing their best to minimise the risks of concussion in the sport.

node.title: Covid-19: Health officials investigate death of person while isolating at home
node.description: Health officials are investigating the death of a person who had Covid-19 and was isolating at home in Auckland.

node.title: Greece tightens restrictions on the unvaccinated as virus cases spike.
node.description: The restrictions start Saturday and target unvaccinated people, said the country’s health minister, Thanos Plevris.

node.title: As deadlines loom, the U.S. military grants few vaccine exemptions.
node.description: By Jennifer Steinhauer

node.title: Equestrian Jumping Is Set to Be Dropped From Modern Pentathlon
node.description: Claims of animal abuse at the Tokyo Olympics could lead to the biggest change to modern pentathlon in more than a century.

node.title: Authorities Fear for Safety of Missing Woman Who Spent 4 Years as Al-Qaeda Hostage
node.description: The woman apparently returned to Mali to find her adopted daughter after she experienced issues transitioning back into life in Europe, French media reported.

node.title: As COVID Surges, Protesters Hit Streets of Ukraine to Decry Vaccine Mandates
node.description: Over a thousand people blocked streets leading to the Ukrainian capital on November 3 during an anti-vaccination protest.

node.title: The journey to Cleo Smith being found
node.description: Police spent 18 days trying to find little Cleo Smith after she disappeared from the remote Blowholes campsite. Here's how the search unfolded.

node.title: Eight million Australian homes aren't energy efficient. Many occupants are battling change
node.description: Eight million Australian homes contribute to 18 per cent of Australia's carbon emissions, a new report shows. Enacting any major change is especially hard for renters and people in low-income households.

node.title: Australia has a submarine-shaped hole in its defences, and few options to fill it
node.description: The navy faces a looming headache on how to replace its ageing submarine fleet, one that a hurt French ambassador warns could create a 20-year hole in Australia's defences.

node.title: Maria James's family calls for a priest's exhumation, if DNA testing doesn't offer answers
node.description: At a fresh coronial inquest into the death of a Victorian woman, the coroner warns the family of Maria James they may not get the answers they hope for, however, the answers may be found in a laboratory.

node.title: Fed to start removing support for economy as inflation surges
node.description: The central bank said it will start reducing its $120 billion in monthly bond purchases in the coming weeks.

node.title: Cheers, tears, comfort dogs and Disney balloons: Covid shots for children get underway in a Texas hospital.
node.description: An 8-year-old eager to hang out with friends said, “It didn’t hurt that much, but it kind of hurt.” A sixth-grader getting vaccinated on her birthday enthused, “This is the best day ever!”

node.title: When Women Filmmakers Get to Tell Their Origin Stories
node.description: Movies about men who make movies are common, but female auteurs don’t often get such chances. That’s just one reason two new releases are so surprising.

node.title: Farmers' fury as national park fire threatens livelihoods for fourth time in five years
node.description: The Queensland government expects responsible land management from farmers, but a grazier who neighbours a national park says it doesn't follow its own rules.

node.title: Everything you need to know about ICUs and the battle to keep COVID-19 patients alive
node.description: It's the part of the hospital where health professionals provide specialised and critical care to those who need it most. If you're a COVID-19 patient, it's the last place you want to end up.

node.title: Carnarvon residents describe man taken into police custody over Cleo Smith disapperance
node.description: Local residents give details about the man living in the house where Western Australia Police found Cleo Smith.

node.title: An important detail Morrison omits when he says Australia barely contributes to global warming
node.description: China's President was a no show at the Glasgow climate summit. It didn't go unnoticed by world leaders, but pointing the blame at China conveniently leaves out an important detail when it comes to global emissions.

node.title: Australia was planning to phase out caged eggs by 2036, but one state is threatening to derail that
node.description: Australia's long-awaited plan to phase out battery hens may be in doubt because of a so-called "captain's call" by a state minister, documents obtained under FOI laws reveal.

node.title: Funding brings military-grade Whanganui Covid response
node.description: A military-style crisis response will be set up with millions of dollars of new funding for the Māori Covid-19 vaccination effort around Whanganui.

node.title: ACC staff posted clients' details to Snapchat group
node.description: ACC call centre workers shared details of people's injuries and mocked them on Snapchat, RNZ can reveal.

node.title: 'I think it's a terrible idea' - Hundreds of car parks across Auckland could be removed
node.description: Auckland Council's planning committee is voting on Auckland Transport's new strategy, which could remove parking spots on main arterial routes and in some parts of the city as a way of curbing diesel…

node.title: Eric Adams Vows to ‘Get Stuff Done.’ But First, a Night on the Town.
node.description: The next mayor of New York City, who celebrated at a downtown club with V.I.P.s, says he will focus on public safety and the crisis at Rikers Island.

node.title: Google Wants to Work With the Pentagon Again, Despite Employee Concerns
node.description: Three years ago, the company walked away from a Defense Department project after employees objected to it. Now the company is working on a new proposal for the Pentagon.

node.title: Max Fried Lost Game 2. Then He Pitched Atlanta to a Title.
node.description: Atlanta’s ace erased the memory of a bad outing by keeping Houston off balance and throwing six scoreless innings.

node.title: Toni Tipton-Martin Writes Her Own Legacy
node.description: The cookbook author, who will receive the seventh Julia Child Award on Thursday, is using the prize money to start a foundation to support women in food.

node.title: George Floyd Family Urges Need to 'Change Current System' After City Votes to Keep Police
node.description: Minneapolis voters on Tuesday rejected a proposition to disband the police and replace it with a "public-health oriented" Department of Public Safety.

node.title: Genesis links $100m loan interest rate to emissions targets
node.description: Genesis Energy has borrowed $100 million from Westpac New Zealand, with the interest rate dependent on meeting emissions reduction targets.

node.title: Covid-19 wrap: Travel may be on cards for Aucklanders, vaccine exemption concerns
node.description: Aucklanders may be able to travel beyond the region's borders by Christmas, officials warn of paid phony vaccine exemptions, and another 4.7 million doses of Pfizer have been purchased.

node.title: Brooklyn Nets star Kevin Durant starts $200 million SPAC
node.description: NBA star's Infinite Acquisition wants to merge with a company in the food, sports, health or cryptocurrency space.

node.title: Howard University says student protests caused layoffs
node.description: Students claim that mold, mice, roaches and fleas are common in dorms and are demanding change.

node.title: Jacob Frey, who oversaw Minneapolis when George Floyd was murdered, wins a second term as mayor.
node.description: The mayoral race was shaped by Mr. Floyd death at the hands of a police officer and the debate about whether to replace the city’s Police Department.

node.title: Republicans broke through in Virginia, but not for the usual reasons.
node.description: Glenn Youngkin won by making broad gains over Democrats in every part of the state and, apparently, across every demographic group.

node.title: Officials Have a ‘Working Theory’ About Jetpack Mystery Over Los Angeles
node.description: The theory, circulated by the Federal Aviation Administration, was announced after images and video taken by a police helicopter were published this week.

node.title: Smartmatic Sues Newsmax and One America News Network, Claiming Defamation
node.description: Smartmatic, an election technology company that faced baseless accusations of rigging the 2020 election, has filed a similar lawsuit against Fox News.

node.title: The New York Sun, a defunct newspaper, plans a comeback after a sale.
node.description: Seth Lipsky sold the publication to Dovid Efune, the former top editor of The Algemeiner Journal. Mr. Lipsky will remain the top editor, and Mr. Efune will be publisher and chairman.

node.title: Satellites Could Help Track if Nations Keep Their Carbon Pledges
node.description: Scientists used satellite measurements of carbon dioxide to detect small atmospheric reductions over areas under coronavirus lockdowns. The approach could help track emissions more quickly in the future.

node.title: Review: Reimagined Gibney Company Makes a Long-Winded Debut
node.description: Gina Gibney unveils an expanded company in three premieres by Sonya Tayeh, Alan Lucien Oyen and Rena Butler at the Joyce Theater.

node.title: Aaron Rodgers, Reportedly Unvaccinated, to Miss Time After Once Stating He Was 'Immunized'
node.description: The quarterback has dodged the question about vaccinations in the past, and he will now miss Sunday's start against the Kansas City Chiefs.

node.title: Law School to Remove Name of Founder Who Sponsored Massacres of Native Americans
node.description: The University of California Hastings College of the Law voted to change its name to distance itself from its founder's attacks against Indigenous people

node.title: Prosecco, Prosekar: Italy, Croatia Battle Over Naming Rights to World's Most Popular Wine
node.description: The most popular type of wine in the world is the subject of a bitter naming rights battle between Croatia and Italy.

node.title: 'Just a Dollar a Day': For-Profit Prison Ordered to Pay Detainees $23M for Wage Theft
node.description: "This is a landmark victory for workers' rights and basic human dignity," Washington Attorney General Bob Ferguson said.

node.title: Plan to build green hydrogen fuelling stations begins
node.description: Hiringa Energy is investing $50 million to build the four stations along key transport routes in the North Island.

node.title: Island nations could sue over climate change
node.description: Antigua and Barbuda, in the Caribbean, and Pacific nation Tuvalu have formed a commission that will ask an international tribunal if they can claim damages.

node.title: Henry Ruggs was driving at 156 mph before deadly crash, police say
node.description: The 22-year-old was released from the team hours after police said he would face a felony driving under the influence charge.

node.title: Winsome Sears elected lieutenant governor of Virginia
node.description: Sears is a conservative who ran alongside Republican Glenn Youngkin.

node.title: Satellite monitoring of emissions from countries and companies ‘changes everything,’ Al Gore says.
node.description: Real-time checks on where greenhouse gases are being produced may prove a powerful weapon in the fight to cool the earth.

node.title: Virginia’s Fight Over ‘Beloved’
node.description: Glenn Youngkin ran for governor on a “parents’ rights” platform.

node.title: Fed Announces Plan to Slow Its Bond Buying Program
node.description: The Federal Reserve is dealing with high inflation at a time when millions of workers remain on the job market’s sidelines.

node.title: After the Election: Worries for Democrats
node.description: Readers analyze the Democrats' poor showing in the election. Also: Fatal beatings of children; from Facebook to Meta.

node.title: Man Gets 4 Years in Prison for Exporting Used Medical Gloves, Equipment to U.S.
node.description: Pipatpon Homjanya was an employee of Paddy the Room Trading Co., which Thai officials said exported millions of cases of the gloves.

node.title: 'It's the best news the town could have asked for': Despair turns to joy for Carnarvon
node.description: Searchers head to the local to pub to celebrate after four-year-old Cleo Smith found alive and well.

node.title: As Australia's border restrictions lift, I'm nervous about returning home. Here's why
node.description: Australia may be starting to reopen its borders, but after months of yearning to come home, I find myself nervous about the prospect of returning. I wonder how I can sit at Christmas or Easter lunch knowing the person passing the salt thought it was reasonable to leave me in the wilderness during an international crisis, writes Rebekah Ison.

node.title: It turns out whales eat a lot more than we thought — but that's a good thing
node.description: Whales consume three times more food than previously thought, and their role in ocean ecosystems and the impact of whaling may have been vastly underestimated.

node.title: What a palliative care doctor has learnt about delivering bad news
node.description: After having a painful experience as a junior doctor, Kathryn Mannix learnt how to handle important or 'tender' conversations more successfully.

node.title: It's hard to remember a PM's trip running off the rails so spectacularly
node.description: The Prime Minister was yesterday imploring everyone to "move on" from Australia's diplomatic row with France over the submarine deal. Perhaps they soon will. But it's difficult to see much prospect of repair in the relationship while Morrison and Macron are both in power, writes David Speers.

node.title: Ballot initiatives to increase housing won big on Tuesday, a possible harbinger for 2022.
node.description: The trend could be a harbinger of more ballot choices in 2022, as more cities and states take aim at rising rents.

node.title: Trading for Von Miller, the Rams Are All In
node.description: Los Angeles’s front office has been aggressive in pursuing trades that can help the team return to the Super Bowl, frequently raiding its store of draft picks to do so.

node.title: Bitcoin Millionaire Zaryn Dentzel Says He Was Beaten, Had Fortune Stolen in Masked Robbery
node.description: The thieves allegedly entered the home of the tech entrepreneur before forcing him to reveal the password to his cryptocurrency account.

node.title: Women Across the Country Are Winning Elections, Here Is Who's Taking Office
node.description: The 2021 contests yielded several historic firsts, including the city of Boston and the state of Virginia choosing a woman of color for top political offices.

node.title: Man Threatens McDonald's Employee, Breaks COVID Barrier After Refusing to Wear Mask
node.description: "In all honesty, no one ever deserves to go to work to be treated like that…," one user commented on the now-viral video.

node.title: Videos Showing Long Lines Over Chipotle's '$5 Bowl' Offer Spark Debate
node.description: Videos surfacing online have shown packed restaurants and long waits for orders, and many have been left concerned for the workers who have to deal with the annual offer.

node.title: Connecticut Hospital Gave COVID Vaccine to 7 Kids Minutes After CDC Gave Go-Ahead
node.description: The kid-sized doses of Pfizer's vaccine were pushed through their two final checkpoints Tuesday after CDC advisers and the CDC director gave their approval.

node.title: Kagan, Barrett Question Whether Times Square, Colleges in New York Could Allow Gun Bans
node.description: Supreme Court justices appeared skeptical during Wednesday's oral arguments on whether or not New York's gun permit law should be struck down.
